wordpressPost.title: Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup: 12/19/2014
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top articles from around the industry so that you can stay up-to-date on the state of employee engagement in CSR and sustainability on the go.

Memo to Executives: Well-being Boosts Employee Engagement

There is a misconception that focusing on well-being at work hurts productivity. However, if done right, well-being programs can decrease employee health costs and allow employees to perform at their best. Gallup has shown that engagement programs with a well-being focus thrive and accelerate, and therefore has co-developed a comprehensive well-being measurement system: The Gallup-Healthways Well-being 5.

Engaged Employees: Your Company’s No. 1 Competitive Advantage

According to Boston Consulting Group, companies that have made the 100 Best Places to Work list for three or more years outperformed the S&P 500 in 8 out of 10 years. Companies with high engagement scores surpassed low-scoring companies in the following key operational areas: productivity, absenteeism, turnover, safety & quality incidents, customer metrics, and profitability. The article finishes by emphasizing the importance of putting employees back in the driver’s seat of their own lives by providing health & well-being programs and encouraging a healthy work-life balance.

Why Consumer Education is Vital for Corporate Sustainability Success

Vice President of Social and Environmental Sustainability at Levi Strauss & Co. explains the value of consumer education when it comes to decreasing the 26 billion pounds of textiles that end up in landfills each year in the US. Besides providing care tags on all Levi’s and Dockers products that encourage consumers to wash less, wash in cold, line dry, and donate when no longer needed Levi’s collected more than 18,850 pairs of jeans for their Field of Jeans donation project in the Bay Area. Levi’s campaign is a great example of how a big impact can be made by small consumer acts.

Study: Most Companies Don’t Have an Employee Engagement Strategy

Research firm, Altimeter Group, released a report based on survey results of HR and marketing executives at 114 companies. Results show that only 41% of respondents said their company has a strategy in place for employee engagement and advocacy. The report also reveals that the #1 problem is the lack of coordination between HR and marketing to achieve engagement goals. The most interesting facts: HR leads employee engagement initiatives at 41% of companies, while marketing leads efforts at 11%, however marketing is more involved (47%) than HR (39%) in actual engagement efforts.

5 Ways to be Happier at Work

Most people spend more time working than participating in any other activity. Therefore, the author suggests 5 simple habit changes to improve satisfaction at work. The specific proven tactics can help you be happier at work and include actions such as changing a few items on your desk, building strong work connections, and increasing self awareness. Our company favorite is #3’what is yours?
